drain-coconut.step_contents: Poke a hole in the “eye” of the coconut with a screwdriver and a mallet. Position the pointed end of a screwdriver on one of the 3 holes or “eyes” at the top of the coconut. Then, use a mallet or hammer to carefully but forcefully bore a hole through an eye. Once the screwdriver gives (indicating it’s bored through the shell), remove it by wiggling it out, widening the new hole in the process. Turn the coconut upside down over a glass and allow it to drain. Let the coconut sit for several minutes or until all of the liquid drains out. You may need to shake the coconut a few times to get the last bit of water out of it.

 Turn the coconut upside down over a glass and allow it to drain. 
 Let the coconut sit for several minutes or until all of the liquid drains out. 
 You may need to shake the coconut a few times to get the last bit of water out of it.

crack-coconut.step_contents: Wrap the mature coconut in a kitchen towel. Place the coconut in the center of the towel, and gather the corners of the towel together to form a pouch. This will keep coconut bits from flying when you go to smash it with a hammer. Use a hammer or mallet to firmly strike all around the coconut. Place the wrapped coconut on a solid surface and hold it in place with one hand. Then, minding your fingers, strike the coconut’s center with a hammer or mallet. Turn the wrapped coconut slightly, and strike the center again. Use as much force as you can safely apply, and repeat until the coconut breaks apart beneath the towel. Alternatively, strike the coconut against a concrete surface. If you don’t have a hammer or mallet, you can use a solid surface like a porch or possibly a concrete countertop. Try to strike the coconut’s equator against the corner of this surface, using it as a makeshift wedge. Repeatedly strike the coconut all around its equator until the coconut breaks apart. Use a knife to separate the meat from the shell. Remove the coconut pieces from the towel. Take each piece, and wedge a knife between the shell and the white meat of the coconut to carefully separate the two. Then, use the knife (or a vegetable peeler) or remove the fibrous layer that might still be clinging to the outside of the meat.

crack-hot-coconut.step_contents: Preheat the oven to 400 °F (204 °C) and bake the coconut for 15-20 minutes. Place the mature coconut on a baking sheet, and monitor it as it bakes (you only want to bake the coconut for as long as it takes to form a crack—baking it for much longer may burn it). After 15 minutes, check for cracks in the coconut. If no cracks have formed, give it another 5 minutes in the oven, or until the coconut has developed fault lines. Alternatively, microwave the coconut on high for 3 minutes. This method is handy when you’re pressed for time, or don’t want to fuss around with an oven. The coconut may not crack, and you may need to exert more force to open it later, but the shell will become weaker and generally easier to penetrate. Remove the coconut and wrap it in a towel to cool. Use oven mitts to retrieve the coconut from the oven or microwave, and allow it to cool for about 5 minutes while wrapped in a towel. Doing this ensures you don’t have hot coconut bits flying everywhere when you go to smash it in the next step. Whack the wrapped coconut with a hammer, or bash it against a hard surface. With the coconut still wrapped in the towel, use a hammer or a mallet to repeatedly and forcefully whack the coconut. Turn the coconut as you hammer it, in order to strike it from multiple angles. Hammer it until you feel it break open beneath the towel. Separate the coconut meat from the shell with a knife. Take each coconut fragment and slip a knife between the shell and the white meat of the coconut to separate the two. Then, use the knife to remove the fibrous layer that might still be clinging to the outside of the meat, in a similar manner to how you’d peel an apple.

Then, use the knife to remove the fibrous layer that might still be clinging to the outside of the meat, in a similar manner to how you’d peel an apple.

full-open-coconut.step_contents:
Poke a hole in the “eye” of the coconut with a screwdriver and a mallet. Position the pointed end of a screwdriver on one of the 3 holes or “eyes” at the top of the coconut. Then, use a mallet or hammer to carefully but forcefully bore a hole through an eye. Once the screwdriver gives (indicating it’s bored through the shell), remove it by wiggling it out, widening the new hole in the process. Turn the coconut upside down over a glass and allow it to drain. Let the coconut sit for several minutes or until all of the liquid drains out. You may need to shake the coconut a few times to get the last bit of water out of it.

Wrap the mature coconut in a kitchen towel. Place the coconut in the center of the towel, and gather the corners of the towel together to form a pouch. This will keep coconut bits from flying when you go to smash it with a hammer. Use a hammer or mallet to firmly strike all around the coconut. Place the wrapped coconut on a solid surface and hold it in place with one hand. Then, minding your fingers, strike the coconut’s center with a hammer or mallet. Turn the wrapped coconut slightly, and strike the center again. Use as much force as you can safely apply, and repeat until the coconut breaks apart beneath the towel. Alternatively, strike the coconut against a concrete surface. If you don’t have a hammer or mallet, you can use a solid surface like a porch or possibly a concrete countertop. Try to strike the coconut’s equator against the corner of this surface, using it as a makeshift wedge. Repeatedly strike the coconut all around its equator until the coconut breaks apart. Use a knife to separate the meat from the shell. Remove the coconut pieces from the towel. Take each piece, and wedge a knife between the shell and the white meat of the coconut to carefully separate the two. Then, use the knife (or a vegetable peeler) or remove the fibrous layer that might still be clinging to the outside of the meat.

Alternatively, microwave the coconut on high for 3 minutes. This method is handy when you’re pressed for time, or don’t want to fuss around with an oven. The coconut may not crack, and you may need to exert more force to open it later, but the shell will become weaker and generally easier to penetrate. Then, use the knife to remove the fibrous layer that might still be clinging to the outside of the meat, in a similar manner to how you’d peel an apple.

coconut: After 15 minutes, check for cracks in the coconut.
Alternatively, microwave the coconut on high for 3 minutes.
Alternatively, strike the coconut against a concrete surface.
Doing this ensures you don’t have hot coconut bits flying everywhere when you go to smash it in the next step.
If no cracks have formed, give it another 5 minutes in the oven, or until the coconut has developed fault lines.
If you don’t have a hammer or mallet, you can use a solid surface like a porch or possibly a concrete countertop.
Let the coconut sit for several minutes or until all of the liquid drains out.
Once the screwdriver gives (indicating it’s bored through the shell), remove it by wiggling it out, widening the new hole in the process.
Place the coconut in the center of the towel, and gather the corners of the towel together to form a pouch.
Place the mature coconut on a baking sheet, and monitor it as it bakes (you only want to bake the coconut for as long as it takes to form a crack—baking it for much longer may burn it).
Place the wrapped coconut on a solid surface and hold it in place with one hand.
Poke a hole in the “eye” of the coconut with a screwdriver and a mallet.
Position the pointed end of a screwdriver on one of the 3 holes or “eyes” at the top of the coconut.
Preheat the oven to 400 °F (204 °C) and bake the coconut for 15-20 minutes.
Remove the coconut and wrap it in a towel to cool.
Remove the coconut pieces from the towel.
Repeatedly strike the coconut all around its equator until the coconut breaks apart.
Separate the coconut meat from the shell with a knife.
Take each coconut fragment and slip a knife between the shell and the white meat of the coconut to separate the two.
Take each piece, and wedge a knife between the shell and the white meat of the coconut to carefully separate the two.
The coconut may not crack, and you may need to exert more force to open it later, but the shell will become weaker and generally easier to penetrate.
Then, minding your fingers, strike the coconut’s center with a hammer or mallet.
Then, use a mallet or hammer to carefully but forcefully bore a hole through an eye.
Then, use the knife (or a vegetable peeler) or remove the fibrous layer that might still be clinging to the outside of the meat.
Then, use the knife to remove the fibrous layer that might still be clinging to the outside of the meat, in a similar manner to how you’d peel an apple.
Turn the coconut as you hammer it, in order to strike it from multiple angles.
Turn the coconut upside down over a glass and allow it to drain.
Turn the wrapped coconut slightly, and strike the center again.
Use a hammer or mallet to firmly strike all around the coconut.
Use a knife to separate the meat from the shell.
Use as much force as you can safely apply, and repeat until the coconut breaks apart beneath the towel.
Use oven mitts to retrieve the coconut from the oven or microwave, and allow it to cool for about 5 minutes while wrapped in a towel.
Whack the wrapped coconut with a hammer, or bash it against a hard surface.

wikihow_title: How to Open a Coconut with a Hammer, Oven, or Microwave

move.description: Move from location A to location B via direction D
move.prerequisites: Player in location A, locations connected by direction

get.prerequisites: Player in same location as item, item not on top or under another item

drop.prerequisites: Item in player's inventory, player at location
drop.results: Item removed from inventory, placed at location

position.description: Stack item A on item B
position.prerequisites: Player and items in same location, neither item pressed

remove.description: Unstack item A from item B
remove.prerequisites: Player and items in same location, item A on item B
remove.results: Item A unstacked from item B

poke.prerequisites: All items and player in same location, screwdriver on coconut, hammer on screwdriver, hammer not pressed

takeout.description: Remove item A from inside item B
takeout.prerequisites: Player and items at same location, item A inside item B, item A not pressed
takeout.results: Item A removed from item B

drain.prerequisites: Player and items in same location, coconut on container, coconut has hole, coconut has water
drain.results: Coconut has no water, container has water

wrap.prerequisites: Player and items at same location, towel and coconut not pressed

strike.prerequisites: Player and items at same location, hammer on towel, towel on coconut, hammer not pressed

smash.prerequisites: Player and coconut at ground location, coconut not open, coconut has no water, coconut not pressed nor on top of another item

preheat.prerequisites: Player at oven, oven is not hot

bake.prerequisites: Player at oven, coconut in inventory, oven is hot
bake.results: Coconut is heated, oven is not hot

heat.prerequisites: Player at microwave, coconut in inventory

separatemeat.prerequisites: Player and items at same location, knife on coconut, coconut is open, coconut has meat, knife not pressed
separatemeat.results: Coconut has no meat, meat at location

in.description: Item A is inside item B

on.description: Item A is on item B

ontop.description: Item is on top of another item

connected.description: Location A is connected to location B via direction
